Package io.github.ai4ci.abm

package io.github.ai4ci.abm
High-level documentation for the agent-based modelling package io.github.ai4ci.abm.

This package implements an agent-based infectious disease model with the following primary capabilities and design conventions. The intent of this package-level javadoc is to help developers and modelers understand where key behaviours are implemented, where to change model assumptions, and how the pieces interact.

Core modelling concepts

  • Agents — represented by Person objects. Each agent has both a static demographic description (PersonDemographic) and time-stamped state/history objects (PersonState and PersonHistory).
  • Temporal states — shared behaviour and measurements that are meaningful at a particular model time are exposed via PersonTemporalState. This includes in-host quantities (viral load, severity), contact exposure accumulated that day, and flags such as isInfectious(), isSymptomatic(), and incident markers.
  • Outbreak and configuration — global parameters and model setup live in Outbreak and its configuration helpers (e.g. ExecutionConfiguration and SetupConfiguration). Change default tests, thresholds and timing by editing the relevant configuration objects.

Network interactions

The social contact network is modelled as weighted relationships between agents. Key points:

  • SocialRelationship encapsulates an edge between two agents and stores a relationship strength quantile. The per-day probability of a contact is modelled as relationshipStrength * adjMobility(personA) * adjMobility(personB) via SocialRelationship.contactProbability(double,double).
  • Contacts produced by these relationships (and other mobility-driven interactions) are materialised as Contact objects and stored in daily histories (PersonHistory.getTodaysContacts()).
  • Additional context (masking, venue, duration) is encoded in contact weights and influences per-contact transmission risk; augment or replace that logic by changing the contact-building phase of the simulation (see social network / mobility generators and any calibration code).

In-host dynamics and viral load

The model separates within-host dynamics from population processes. Relevant behaviours:

  • Each PersonTemporalState exposes two continuous in-host signals: normalised viral load and normalised severity. Values are scaled so that 0 denotes no detectable infection and 1 denotes a baseline infectious level. This scale is used throughout the codebase to compare exposures, determine detectability by tests, and decide symptomatic / hospitalisation events.
  • A person is considered infectious when isInfectious() returns true — implemented by thresholding getNormalisedViralLoad() against an infectivity cutoff supplied by the setup configuration.
  • Daily exposure accumulation (the sum of viral doses experienced that day) is recorded via getContactExposure() and stored as Exposure entries in the exposee's PersonHistory when transmission occurs.
  • Incubation and infectious period assumptions used by the model are available from the ModelNav / model state accessors. Use incubPeriod() and infPeriod() to read the current working values.

Testing, sensitivity and specificity

Testing behaviour is captured by TestResult and TestParameters:

  • Viral load sampling: When a test is taken the model records the true viral load truth (from PersonTemporalState.getNormalisedViralLoad()) and then simulates measurement noise with TestParameters.applyNoise(double, io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler) to produce a sampled value (TestResult.getViralLoadSample()).
  • Limit of detection (LoD): Each TestParameters defines a limit of detection. The final observed result compares the noisy sample against the LoD to determine a positive/negative observation.
  • Sensitivity: In this codebase sensitivity is represented implicitly by the combination of the LoD and the noise model: for a given true viral load, the probability that the noisy sample exceeds the LoD maps to the empirical sensitivity. The default test types (e.g. LFT, PCR) provide baseline TestParameters that can be modified via the execution configuration.
  • Specificity: Specificity is modelled as the probability that an individual with very low viral load produces a sample below the LoD. TestParameters also supply explicit specificity values used to compute likelihood ratios (TestParameters.positiveLikelihoodRatio() and TestParameters.negativeLikelihoodRatio()).
  • Delays: Test processing delay is sampled (log-normal) using parameters in TestParameters and influences when results become observable.
  • Evidence and likelihoods: The model computes log-likelihood ratios for results (TestResult.trueLogLikelihoodRatio()) which are used to update agent-level estimates of infection probability (e.g., for smart agents or contact tracing logic).

Tracing exposures and diagnostic history

Daily contacts, exposures and tests are stored in the agent's PersonHistory. Exposures link back to the infecting agent via Exposure.getExposerId(); use Exposure.getExposer(io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonTemporalState) to resolve the exposer's PersonHistory at the relevant time.

Extension points and where to change behaviour

  • Network generation and contact probability: modify the social network / mobility generators or change SocialRelationship.contactProbability(double,double) if you want different functional forms for contact likelihood.
  • In-host dynamics: replace or adjust the model that populates PersonTemporalState.getNormalisedViralLoad() and PersonTemporalState.getNormalisedSeverity() if you need alternate within-host dynamics or scaling.
  • Testing regimes and properties: edit available TestParameters in ExecutionConfiguration to change sensitivity, specificity, LoD or delay distributions. Use TestResult.Type.modify() to start from a default and tune parameters programmatically.
  • Thresholds and timing: incubation and infectious period assumptions are surfaced via ModelNav and the outbreak configuration; change them in the global configuration or in calibration code used before runs.

Behaviour and policy state models

The runtime decision logic for both individuals and the system-wide policy is implemented using the state model framework found in State and driven by StateMachine and StateMachineContext:

  • State types: Two complementary flavours of state are supported:
    • BehaviourState — an enum-based state model that implements individual behaviour logic (mobility, compliance, testing behaviour). These states operate on PersonState and update PersonHistory.
    • PolicyState — an enum-based state model that implements system-level policy logic (population-level interventions, testing strategies, or triggering of new policies). These states operate on OutbreakState and update OutbreakHistory.
  • Update phases: The state framework separates the daily update into two phases implemented by State.updateHistory(Object,Object,io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics.StateMachineContext,io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler) (executed in the history stage) and State.nextState(Object,Object,io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics.StateMachineContext,io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler) (executed at the state update stage). The history update is the appropriate place for actions that materialise during the day (e.g. scheduling tests, recording contacts) while the nextState step computes the behavioural or policy state that should apply on the following day.
  • Policy-to-behaviour interaction: Policies can directly influence individuals in two ways:
    1. By mutating the OutbreakState (via the policy state's builder) the policy can change global parameters (e.g. available tests, thresholds, or contact restrictions) which are then observed by individuals when they compute their next state.
    2. By branching people into different behaviour models: policy states may call StateUtils.branchPeopleTo(io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState, io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics.State.BehaviourState) (or similar helpers) to immediately push individuals into a different behaviour model. The StateMachine.rememberCurrentState(io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics.State) and StateMachine.forceTo(io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics.State.PolicyState) semantics control how model switching is tracked and reversed.
  • Behaviour update semantics: Behaviour models are implemented as enums that implement State.BehaviourState. In their nextState implementation they receive the current PersonState and a StateMachineContext object containing recent policy-level signals and context. Behaviour states can modify the ImmutablePersonState.Builder (the next state builder) to schedule actions such as testing or isolation, and return the behaviour enum that should apply tomorrow.
  • Where to change or extend: To add or alter policy/behaviour logic look at
    • State — the state interface and subtypes;
    • StateMachine — orchestration of history and state updates;
    • StateMachineContext — shared context/flags used by states;
    • StateUtils — helper functions used by states to implement common actions (branching, forcing, or recording events);
    • Updater — the component that drives the simulation update cycle and invokes state update hooks for both outbreak and agents.

Policy modelling notes

  • PolicyState implementations should be conservative about making irreversible changes to individuals' next states because behaviour models may subsequently override them. Use the state-machine branching helpers if you need immediate, coordinated changes across the population.
  • Policy models can be used to implement dynamic testing strategies (for example switching which tests are available or changing priorities), trigger contact tracing workflows, or alter population-level mobility multipliers that affect SocialRelationship.contactProbability(double,double) outcomes.

Examples and entry points

Look at the example experiment and baseline implementations to see the pattern in practice:

  • Experiment — demonstrates configuration of behaviour models and tests (see examples folder).
  • OutbreakBaseline — provides default policy/behaviour baseline states and wiring into the state machine on simulation start.

  • Class
    Description
    Abstraction
    Base interface defining abstraction layers for modeling different levels of detail in agent behavior and mathematical operations within the agent-based modeling framework.
    Abstraction.Entity
    Base interface for identifiable entities within the modeling framework.
    Abstraction.HistoricalStateProvider<H extends Abstraction.TemporalState<?>>
    Interface for providing access to historical state data.
    Abstraction.Named
    Interface for objects that have a name identifier.
    Abstraction.Replica
    Interface for objects that support replica/simulation run tracking.
    Abstraction.TemporalState<E extends Abstraction.Entity>
    Interface for temporal states that track entity evolution over time.
    Calibration
    Various utilities to calibrate model to real world observations.
    Calibration.Estimator
    An optimized estimator for the expected probability of transmission across a social network edge given a transmission parameter and viral load profiles.
    Contact
    A contact between two people.
    Exposure
    Represents a successful transmission event from an infectious individual (exposer) to another individual (exposee).
    HistoryMapper
    Generated mapping from current state to history entries.
    ModelNav
    Convenience navigation helpers for extracting model-level information from temporal state objects and related entities.
    ModelUpdate
    Collection of pre-packaged model update functions (hooks) that are applied during the simulation update cycle.
    ModelUpdate.OutbreakUpdaterFn
    Outbreak-level updaters: run once per day during the updateState phase (see Updater.updateState(Outbreak)).
    ModelUpdate.PersonUpdaterFn
    Person-level updaters: run for every person during the updateState phase (see Updater.updateState(Person)).
    Outbreak
    The central mutable container for an entire simulation instance.
    OutbreakBaseline
    Simulation wide parameters that do not change over the course of the simulation.
    OutbreakHistory
    The historical state of the whole model.
    OutbreakState
    The current state of the outbreak.
    OutbreakTemporalState
    Any data related to the state of the outbreak which is valid only in a specific time point.
    Person
    The main Person class is a mutable holder that contains immutable data pertaining to baseline, current state, recent history etc.
    PersonBaseline
    Baseline parameters for a person in the simulation.
    PersonDemographic
    Represents the demographic information of a Person in the simulation.
    PersonHistory
    Historical patient data relevant to the ongoing simulation.
    PersonState
    The person's current state within a single simulation timestep.
    PersonTemporalState
    Any data related to the state of the people in the model which is valid only in a specific time point.
    SocialRelationship
    Represents a weighted social relationship (an edge) between two individuals in the simulation's social network.
    TestResult
    Models a testing process and its outcome for an individual in the simulation.
    TestResult.Indication
    Defines the indication for which a test was performed.
    TestResult.Result
    Represents the possible outcomes of a test.
    TestResult.Type
    Defines the types of tests available in the simulation, each with its specific parameters.
